title: Jeremiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 26.

questions.question: At the beginning of whose reign did the word of the LORD come to Jeremiah?
options: Jehoiakim
Josiah
Hezekiah
Urijah
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:1 states that the word came in the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah.

questions.question: Where was Jeremiah instructed to stand and speak the LORD's words?
options: In the court of the LORD'S house
At the city gates
On the mountain of the house
In the king's palace
questions.correctAnswer: In the court of the LORD'S house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:2 commands Jeremiah to stand in the court of the LORD'S house and speak to all the cities of Judah.

questions.question: What would happen if the people hearkened and turned from their evil ways?
options: The LORD would repent of the evil He purposed
The city would be destroyed
Jeremiah would be taken away
The priests would be punished
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD would repent of the evil He purposed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:3 explains that if the people turn from evil, the LORD may repent of the evil planned against them.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He would make the house like if the people did not obey?
options: Shiloh
Jerusalem
Bethel
Zion
questions.correctAnswer: Shiloh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:6 says the LORD would make the house like Shiloh if the people did not hearken to Him.

questions.question: Who were gathered against Jeremiah after he finished speaking in the LORD's house?
options: The priests, prophets, and all the people
Only the priests
The king and his princes
Foreign envoys
questions.correctAnswer: The priests, prophets, and all the people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:8-9 states that the priests, prophets, and all the people gathered against Jeremiah.

questions.question: What sentence did the priests and prophets want for Jeremiah?
options: Death
Exile
Imprisonment
Silence
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:8-11 shows that the priests and prophets said Jeremiah should surely die for his prophecy.

questions.question: How did Jeremiah respond to the princes and the people about his prophecy?
options: He said the LORD sent him to prophesy
He asked for forgiveness
He denied speaking against the city
He fled the city
questions.correctAnswer: He said the LORD sent him to prophesy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:12 states that Jeremiah told them the LORD sent him to prophesy against the house and city.

questions.question: What warning did Jeremiah give if they put him to death?
options: They would bring innocent blood upon themselves
The city would be saved
They would be forgiven
Nothing would happen
questions.correctAnswer: They would bring innocent blood upon themselves
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:15 warns that putting him to death would cause them to bring innocent blood upon themselves and the city.

questions.question: What was the verdict of the princes and all the people regarding Jeremiah's worthiness to die?
options: He was not worthy to die
He was worthy to die
They were undecided
They ignored the issue
questions.correctAnswer: He was not worthy to die
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:16 says the princes and all the people declared Jeremiah not worthy to die because he spoke in the name of the LORD.

questions.question: Who was the prophet mentioned as an example of one who prophesied destruction but was not put to death?
options: Micah the Morasthite
Urijah the son of Shemaiah
Ahikam the son of Shaphan
Jehoiakim the king
questions.correctAnswer: Micah the Morasthite
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:18-19 references Micah the Morasthite as a prophet who foretold destruction but was not killed.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 26:7 says only the priests heard Jeremiah's words in the LORD's house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:7 states that the priests, the prophets, and all the people heard Jeremiah.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was immediately put to death after speaking in the LORD's house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:24 explains that Ahikam protected Jeremiah so he was not given to the people to be killed.

questions.question: True or False: Urijah fled to Egypt but was later brought back and killed by the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:21-23 records Urijah's flight to Egypt, his return by force, and subsequent death by King Jehoiakim.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'If ye will not hearken to me, to walk in my ______, which I have set before you,'
options: law
commandments
words
paths
questions.correctAnswer: law
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:4 says, 'If ye will not hearken to me, to walk in my law, which I have set before you.'

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Thus saith the LORD; Stand in the court of the LORD'S house, and speak unto all the ______ of Judah,'
options: cities
people
priests
elders
questions.correctAnswer: cities
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:2 commands Jeremiah to speak to all the cities of Judah that come to worship in the LORD's house.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is hesitant to share God's warnings honestly with others out of fear. Based on Jeremiah 26, what biblical truth would you share about obedience to God’s Word?
options: We must speak all God’s words without diminishing any part of them.
It is acceptable to soften God's message to avoid conflict.
Only share God’s words when people are willing to listen.
Avoid speaking hard truths to maintain peace.
questions.correctAnswer: We must speak all God’s words without diminishing any part of them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:2 instructs Jeremiah to speak all the words God commands without diminishing a word, emphasizing full obedience to God’s Word. Verses 12-15 also demonstrate Jeremiah’s commitment to speaking the full truth despite opposition.

questions.question: A believer struggles with discouragement when others reject their witness. How does Jeremiah 26 teach us to trust God amidst rejection?
options: Trust that God’s plan will prevail even if people reject His message.
Stop sharing if people oppose the message.
Only witness to those who appear receptive.
Change the message to please the crowd.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God’s plan will prevail even if people reject His message.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah continued to prophesy despite being accused and threatened with death (verses 8-15). The chapter shows that God’s word remains true and Jeremiah’s trust in God was steadfast.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 26 teach about humility and submission when facing unjust accusations?
options: Submit yourself to others’ judgment while leaving justice to God.
Defend yourself aggressively to prove your innocence.
Avoid confrontation by remaining silent.
Retaliate against those who accuse you.
questions.correctAnswer: Submit yourself to others’ judgment while leaving justice to God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah says in verse 14, “As for me, behold, I am in your hand: do with me as seemeth good,” showing humility and willingness to submit while trusting God for justice (verses 14-15).

questions.question: A church leader encourages believers to repent from sinful ways. According to Jeremiah 26, why is repentance important for a community?
options: Repentance can cause God to relent from sending judgment.
Repentance is optional and has no effect on God’s plans.
Repentance only benefits the individual, not the community.
Repentance delays blessings but does not change judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance can cause God to relent from sending judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:3 says if the people turn from their evil ways, God will repent of the evil He planned to do. Verses 13-15 also emphasize the call to amend ways and obey God for His mercy.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 26 teach about integrity and faithfulness in delivering God’s message even under threat?
options: Faithfulness means delivering God’s message fully despite risks.
Faithfulness allows for altering the message to avoid danger.
Integrity means protecting oneself by silence.
It is wise to only share parts of the message that are safe.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness means delivering God’s message fully despite risks.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah faithfully spoke all words God commanded without diminishing them (verse 2) even when threatened with death (verses 8-9). This shows integrity and commitment.

questions.question: A believer wonders if God’s warnings through prophets are trustworthy. What principle about prophetic warnings does Jeremiah 26 demonstrate?
options: Prophets sent by God speak truth that must be obeyed.
Prophetic warnings are often exaggerations and may be ignored.
Only some prophets speak for God, so verify carefully.
God’s warnings can be discarded if unpopular.
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets sent by God speak truth that must be obeyed.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 highlights that God sent prophets who warned repeatedly, and disobedience to their words brought consequences (verse 6). The chapter stresses the importance of hearkening to God’s servants.

questions.question: How does the example of Micah in Jeremiah 26 guide believers in trusting God’s mercy after repentance?
options: God can relent from judgment when His people repent and seek Him.
Once God pronounces judgment, it cannot be changed.
Prophets’ warnings are always fatal and irreversible.
Repentance has no role in God’s decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: God can relent from judgment when His people repent and seek Him.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:18-19 recounts how Micah’s prophecy warned of destruction, but because Hezekiah and Judah feared God and prayed, God repented of the evil pronounced.

questions.question: A believer faces opposition for speaking God’s truth. How does Jeremiah 26 encourage perseverance through trials in faithfulness?
options: Continue faithfully even if opposition comes, trusting God’s protection.
Give up if opposition threatens your life.
Change your message to avoid conflict.
Avoid public speaking to stay safe.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfully even if opposition comes, trusting God’s protection.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was threatened with death but continued to declare God’s message (verses 8-15). Additionally, verse 24 shows that God provided protection through Ahikam’s hand.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 26 teaches that a community’s leaders should evaluate prophetic messages carefully rather than condemning the messenger outright.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 16-19 show some elders defending Jeremiah, recalling how past prophets were not put to death and encouraging careful consideration rather than immediate condemnation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 26, fearing God and seeking Him through prayer can influence God's decisions about judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:19 explains that because Hezekiah and Judah feared the LORD and prayed, God repented of the evil He had pronounced, showing prayer’s power to change God’s response.

questions.question: A believer is unsure about the consequences of rejecting God’s Word. Based on Jeremiah 26, what is the consequence for disobedience?
options: God will make the temple and city desolate like Shiloh.
Nothing will happen if people ignore God’s message.
God will bless the city regardless of disobedience.
Only individuals, not the city, will be punished.
questions.correctAnswer: God will make the temple and city desolate like Shiloh.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:6 warns that if the people do not obey, God will make the temple like Shiloh and the city a curse to all nations, showing serious consequences for disobedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah told the people that if they put him to death, they would bring ______ upon themselves and the city.
options: innocent blood
great wealth
peace and blessings
destruction
questions.correctAnswer: innocent blood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:15 states that killing Jeremiah would bring innocent blood upon the people and the city, highlighting the gravity of rejecting God’s messenger.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 26 illustrate the importance of godly leadership in the protection of faithful servants?
options: Ahikam the son of Shaphan protected Jeremiah from being handed over to the people to die.
Leaders ignored Jeremiah and let the people decide his fate.
The king immediately executed Jeremiah without question.
No leader intervened to protect Jeremiah.
questions.correctAnswer: Ahikam the son of Shaphan protected Jeremiah from being handed over to the people to die.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 shows that Ahikam’s hand was with Jeremiah, preventing his death, demonstrating the role of godly leaders in safeguarding faithful ministers.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of consequences when sharing the Gospel. What does Jeremiah 26 teach about trusting God’s purpose in witnessing despite risks?
options: God sends His servants to speak His words regardless of personal danger.
It is better to avoid sharing if there is any risk involved.
Only share the Gospel when safe and accepted.
Fear should prevent us from witnessing.
questions.correctAnswer: God sends His servants to speak His words regardless of personal danger.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was sent by God to prophesy despite threats (verses 12-15), showing that God’s calling to witness transcends fear of consequences.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 26 teach about the biblical virtue of accountability within the community of faith?
options: The community must hear God’s word and amend their ways to avoid judgment.
Individual actions have no impact on the community’s fate.
Only leaders are accountable for the people's sins.
Accountability is unnecessary if one trusts God.
questions.correctAnswer: The community must hear God’s word and amend their ways to avoid judgment.
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 13 call the people to turn from evil and obey God so that He might relent from evil planned, showing communal accountability and need for repentance.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 26.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah commanded to do in the court of the LORD'S house according to Jeremiah 26:2?
options: Speak all the words the LORD commanded without diminishing a word
Offer sacrifices to the LORD
Teach the people to build altars
Sing psalms to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Speak all the words the LORD commanded without diminishing a word
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:2 commands Jeremiah to stand in the court of the LORD'S house and speak all the words that God has commanded him, without diminishing any word.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 26:6, what consequence did the LORD warn would happen if the people did not heed His words?
options: The house would become like Shiloh and the city a curse to all nations
The people would be taken captive to Babylon
The temple would be rebuilt
The land would flow with milk and honey
questions.correctAnswer: The house would become like Shiloh and the city a curse to all nations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:6 states that if the people do not listen, the LORD will make the house like Shiloh and the city a curse, foreshadowing destruction and desolation.

questions.question: Who opposed Jeremiah and sought his death after he finished speaking in the temple court?
options: The priests, the prophets, and all the people
The king and his advisors
The elders of the land
The foreign merchants
questions.correctAnswer: The priests, the prophets, and all the people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:7-8 tells us the priests, prophets, and all the people took Jeremiah and said he must die for his prophecy.

questions.question: What was the chief accusation against Jeremiah by those who wanted him dead as per Jeremiah 26:9?
options: Prophesying that the house would be like Shiloh and the city desolate
Stealing temple treasures
Leading a rebellion against the king
Teaching foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: Prophesying that the house would be like Shiloh and the city desolate
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:9 shows the people accusing Jeremiah of prophesying destruction upon the temple and city, a direct threat to their security and faith.

questions.question: Where did the princes of Judah assemble when they heard about Jeremiah's prophecy according to Jeremiah 26:10?
options: In the entry of the new gate of the LORD'S house
In the king's palace
At the city gate
On the mount of Olives
questions.correctAnswer: In the entry of the new gate of the LORD'S house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:10 states that the princes came from the king's house to sit in the entry of the new gate of the LORD'S house to hear the situation.

questions.question: How did Jeremiah respond to the accusations against him in Jeremiah 26:12?
options: He declared that the LORD sent him to prophesy against the house and city
He denied ever speaking against the city
He blamed the priests for misleading the people
He fled to another city
questions.correctAnswer: He declared that the LORD sent him to prophesy against the house and city
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:12 records Jeremiah's defense that he was sent by the LORD to speak all the words of judgment against the temple and city.

questions.question: What warning did Jeremiah give if they put him to death, according to Jeremiah 26:15?
options: They would bring innocent blood upon themselves and the city
They would be cursed by the LORD forever
Their crops would fail
Their enemies would conquer them immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They would bring innocent blood upon themselves and the city
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 26:15, Jeremiah warns that killing him would cause them to bear the guilt of innocent blood, emphasizing the divine authority behind his message.

questions.question: What was the verdict of the princes and all the people regarding Jeremiah's fate in Jeremiah 26:16?
options: Jeremiah was not worthy to die because he spoke in the name of the LORD
Jeremiah should be imprisoned
Jeremiah should be exiled
Jeremiah should be publicly rebuked
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah was not worthy to die because he spoke in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:16 shows the princes and people declaring Jeremiah not worthy of death, acknowledging his prophecy came from God.

questions.question: Which earlier prophet and king are referenced in Jeremiah 26:18-19 to support Jeremiah’s case?
options: Micah and Hezekiah
Isaiah and Ahaz
Elijah and Ahab
Hosea and Jeroboam
questions.correctAnswer: Micah and Hezekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:18-19 recalls Micah's prophecy in Hezekiah's time, showing that past prophetic warnings were respected and led to repentance.

questions.question: What happened to the prophet Urijah as recorded in Jeremiah 26:21-23?
options: He was killed by King Jehoiakim after being brought back from Egypt
He was honored by the king
He fled and was never heard from again
He became a priest in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He was killed by King Jehoiakim after being brought back from Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:21-23 tells how Urijah fled to Egypt but was brought back and killed by Jehoiakim, showing the king's ruthless suppression of prophecy.

questions.question: Who protected Jeremiah from being handed over to the people for death as mentioned in Jeremiah 26:24?
options: Ahikam the son of Shaphan
King Jehoiakim
The priests
The elders of the land
questions.correctAnswer: Ahikam the son of Shaphan
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:24 says Ahikam son of Shaphan helped protect Jeremiah from being given to the people to be killed, showing political support.

questions.question: Jeremiah 26:3 uses the phrase 'that I may repent me of the evil.' What Hebrew concept does this reflect in terms of God's character?
options: Divine relenting (nacham) showing God's willingness to change judgment upon repentance
God’s immutability without change
God’s predestined plan
God’s wrath without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Divine relenting (nacham) showing God's willingness to change judgment upon repentance
questions.explanation: The Hebrew verb 'nacham' used here expresses God’s relational character, able to relent or change His mind in response to human repentance as in Jeremiah 26:3.

questions.question: The warning that the temple would become like Shiloh (Jeremiah 26:6) is an example of what literary device common in prophetic literature?
options: Typology, linking past destruction to future judgment
Simile comparing temple to a river
Parable about a lost sheep
Allegory of a vineyard
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, linking past destruction to future judgment
questions.explanation: The reference to Shiloh’s destruction serves as typology, foreshadowing the temple’s destruction and connecting past judgment with future consequences.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah showed submission to the people's decision about his fate, stating, 'I am in your hand' (Jeremiah 26:14).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:14 records Jeremiah submitting himself to the people's judgment, demonstrating his humble obedience despite the threat of death.

questions.question: What theme evident in Jeremiah 26 is also prominently developed throughout the prophetic books of the Old Testament?
options: The call to repentance to avoid impending judgment
A promise of immediate military victory
The establishment of a new monarchy
A prophecy of the Messiah’s birth
questions.correctAnswer: The call to repentance to avoid impending judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26 emphasizes the call to repentance to avert divine judgment, a recurring theme in the prophetic corpus of the Old Testament.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah commanded to do at the beginning of Jehoiakim's reign according to Jeremiah 26?
options: Stand in the court of the LORD'S house and speak all the words God commanded
Lead the people in battle against their enemies
Build an altar in the temple
Offer sacrifices to atone for the people's sins
questions.correctAnswer: Stand in the court of the LORD'S house and speak all the words God commanded
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:2 states that the LORD commanded Jeremiah to stand in the court of the LORD'S house and speak all the words He gave without diminishing any word. This reflects God's call for prophetic faithfulness, consistent with Old Testament calls to prophetically warn Israel (cf. Deut 18:18, Ezek 3:17-19, Acts 3:22).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 26, what condition would cause the LORD to repent of the evil He planned to bring upon Judah?
options: If they hearken and turn from their evil ways
If they build more altars for sacrifice
If they increase the number of priests
If they conquer surrounding nations
questions.correctAnswer: If they hearken and turn from their evil ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:3 explains that if the people listen and turn from their evil, God will relent from the planned judgment. This shows God's attribute of mercy and willingness to forgive upon repentance, consistent with passages like 2 Chronicles 7:14, Ezekiel 18:23, and Joel 2:13.

questions.question: What was the fate threatened to Jeremiah by the priests, prophets, and people after his prophecy about the temple and city?
options: He would surely die
He would be exiled
He would be imprisoned
He would be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: He would surely die
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:8 records that the priests, prophets, and people threatened Jeremiah with death because he prophesied destruction upon Jerusalem and the temple. This reflects the rejection prophets often faced (cf. 1 Kings 18:4, Jeremiah 20:2, Matthew 23:37).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah told the princes and people that if they put him to death, they would bring _____ upon themselves and the city.
options: innocent blood
destruction
plague
famine
questions.correctAnswer: innocent blood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:15 warns that killing him would cause innocent blood to be shed on themselves and Jerusalem, emphasizing the sanctity of God's messenger, consistent with the principle in Deuteronomy 19:10 and the New Testament teaching on persecuting God's servants (Acts 22:5).

questions.question: What reason did the princes and people give for deciding Jeremiah was not worthy of death?
options: He spoke in the name of the LORD our God
He performed miracles
He was a relative of the king
He was a trained priest
questions.correctAnswer: He spoke in the name of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:16 states that the princes and people acknowledged Jeremiah's words were from God, which is why they decided not to kill him. This underscores the biblical principle of respecting genuine prophetic authority (cf. Deut 18:20-22, 1 Kings 18:24, Luke 1:70).

questions.question: Which prophet from the days of Hezekiah was mentioned as having prophesied similarly to Jeremiah, warning of Jerusalem's destruction?
options: Micah the Morasthite
Isaiah the son of Amoz
Elijah the Tishbite
Nathan the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Micah the Morasthite
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:18 recalls Micah who prophesied Jerusalem would become desolate, showing that prophetic warnings of judgment were consistent and historically validated. This aligns with Micah 3:12 and the general biblical theme of covenantal judgment.

questions.question: What action did King Jehoiakim take against the prophet Urijah, who prophesied similarly to Jeremiah?
options: He killed him and cast his body into the common graves
He promoted him to a royal advisor
He exiled him to Babylon
He imprisoned him in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He killed him and cast his body into the common graves
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:23 describes Jehoiakim's execution of Urijah, illustrating the hostility toward true prophecy and the dangers prophets faced, consistent with examples like Jeremiah 38:6 and Zechariah 1:15.

questions.question: Who intervened on Jeremiah’s behalf to prevent him from being handed over to the people to be put to death?
options: Ahikam the son of Shaphan
Elnathan the son of Achbor
Jehoiakim the king
Micah the Morasthite
questions.correctAnswer: Ahikam the son of Shaphan
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:24 notes that Ahikam protected Jeremiah from death, showing the role of godly leadership in preserving the prophet and God's word, similar to how figures like Obadiah protected prophets (1 Kings 18:13).

questions.question: What was the content of God's warning through Jeremiah about the temple and city if they did not obey His law?
options: The house would be like Shiloh and the city a curse
The city would be blessed with peace and prosperity
The temple would be rebuilt by foreign nations
The city would become a center of worship for all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The house would be like Shiloh and the city a curse
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:6 warns that if they reject God's law, the temple would be destroyed like Shiloh and the city cursed. Shiloh was a former sacred city that was destroyed due to Israel's disobedience (1 Samuel 4:12-22), illustrating covenantal consequences (cf. Deut 28).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 26, what was the people's reaction immediately after Jeremiah finished speaking all the words of the LORD?
options: They took him and said he must surely die
They praised God for His word
They asked for more teachings
They ignored him and went home
questions.correctAnswer: They took him and said he must surely die
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:8 records that after Jeremiah finished, the priests, prophets, and people sought his death because of his message, demonstrating the rejection of God's warnings, a common prophetic experience (cf. Jeremiah 20:2, Matthew 23:37).

questions.question: What justification did the elders give for sparing Jeremiah’s life, referencing the example of Micah?
options: Hezekiah feared the LORD and God repented of the evil pronounced
Micah was a close relative of the king
Micah performed miracles to prove his prophecy
The people were afraid of divine punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah feared the LORD and God repented of the evil pronounced
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:19 explains that during Micah's time, King Hezekiah feared God and God relented from judgment, teaching the importance of repentance and fear of God for divine mercy (cf. 2 Chronicles 32:25-26, Jonah 3:10).

questions.question: What was Jeremiah’s attitude toward his fate as expressed to the princes and people?
options: He was in their hands and willing to accept whatever they decide
He threatened them with curses if harmed
He fled to avoid persecution
He refused to speak any more
questions.correctAnswer: He was in their hands and willing to accept whatever they decide
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:14 shows Jeremiah’s submission to God’s sovereign will through the people’s judgment, reflecting humility and obedience, consistent with Jesus' submission to the Father’s will (Luke 22:42) and the attitude of other prophets (Acts 21:13).

questions.question: What role did the princes of Judah take upon hearing the accusations against Jeremiah?
options: They came from the king's house and sat in the entry of the new gate of the LORD'S house
They immediately ordered Jeremiah's execution
They sent Jeremiah into exile
They ignored the accusations
questions.correctAnswer: They came from the king's house and sat in the entry of the new gate of the LORD'S house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:10 shows the princes acting judicially by assembling to hear the case against Jeremiah, demonstrating the role of leadership in discerning prophecy, similar to other ancient Israelite judicial scenes (cf. 1 Kings 21:8, Acts 23:1-5).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the theological significance of Jeremiah 26’s prophecy in the grand narrative?
options: It demonstrates God's righteous judgment tempered by mercy upon repentance
It promises unconditional peace regardless of behavior
It focuses mainly on Israel's military victories
It prioritizes temple rituals over ethical conduct
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's righteous judgment tempered by mercy upon repentance
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26 teaches that God’s judgment is just but can be averted by genuine repentance, highlighting His mercy and justice, a theme consistent throughout Scripture (Exodus 34:6-7, Ezekiel 33:11, Romans 2:4).

questions.question: What does the protection of Jeremiah by Ahikam the son of Shaphan reveal about God's providence?
options: God raises up allies to preserve His messengers
God leaves prophets entirely vulnerable
God punishes all who speak truth
God hides His prophets from the people
questions.correctAnswer: God raises up allies to preserve His messengers
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 26:24 shows God’s providential care by using Ahikam to protect Jeremiah, consistent with biblical examples where God provides help for His servants (Exodus 18:13-27, Acts 23:12-24), underscoring divine sovereignty in salvation history.
